abstract.p: Interpublic Group of Companies' One Seven advertising agency staffed by former employees of Saatchi & Saatchi is set to close; Interpublic will try to find jobs at other agencies for some employees while others plan to open agencies of their own (S)

block.p: The tale of the ''Saatchi 17'' is coming to a close for now as the Interpublic Group of Companies ends its financing of One Seven, a money-losing agency in New York that is staffed by former employees of Saatchi & Saatchi, part of the Publicis Groupe.
The so-called Saatchi 17 quit Saatchi & Saatchi en masse in February 2005, three days after their boss, Michael Burns, the former worldwide director of the General Mills account, left the agency.

The tale of the ''Saatchi 17'' is coming to a close for now as the Interpublic Group of Companies ends its financing of One Seven, a money-losing agency in New York that is staffed by former employees of Saatchi & Saatchi, part of the Publicis Groupe.
The so-called Saatchi 17 quit Saatchi & Saatchi en masse in February 2005, three days after their boss, Michael Burns, the former worldwide director of the General Mills account, left the agency.

The employees were all hired by Interpublic, which denied it was hoping that General Mills would follow them to One Seven. Although General Mills never hired One Seven, the agency landed accounts from marketers like ConAgra and Gorton's. Mr. Burns joined One Seven as chairman after the settlement last July of a lawsuit brought against him by Saatchi & Saatchi, which claimed he had arranged the simultaneous departures of the employees.
Interpublic, in a statement Friday, said it would try to find jobs at other Interpublic agencies for some One Seven employees, adding that others were planning to open agencies of their own.
